subject: Re: [junit] test cases for inputs from file
msgSnippet: ... From: Mike Clark  To:  Sent: Monday, September 09, 2002 1:41 PM Subject: Re: [junit] test cases for inputs
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "Mike Clark" <mike@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, September 09, 2002 1:41 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] test cases for inputs from file


> Jonathan Gossage wrote:
>
> >I put thread names into all my logging statements that allow me to see
which
> >thread issued a particular log statement. The messages from the setUp()
and
> >tearDown() methods all were issued from the "main" thread while the
messages
> >from the test methods were issued in "Thread xxx" threads where xxx was
> >different for each test method.
> >
>
> Interesting. What type of environment are these JUnit tests being run in?
>
> I ran the following with JUnit 3.8.1:
>
> import junit.framework.*;
>
> public class ThreadTest extends TestCase {
>
> protected void setUp() {
> System.err.println("setUp: " +
> Thread.currentThread().getName());
> }
>
> protected void tearDown() {
> System.err.println("tearDown: " +
> Thread.currentThread().getName());
> }
>
> public void testThread() {
> System.err.println("testXXX: " +
> Thread.currentThread().getName());
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> return new TestSuite(ThreadTest.class);
> }
>
> public static void main(String[] args) {
> junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
> }
> }
>
> The result was:
>
> setUp: main
> testXXX: main
> tearDown: main
>
>
> Mike
>
I get the same results as you do on 3.7 if I put in the synchronization
statements that I described in my previous post, otherwise I get the results
that I described there. There is a complex test fixture involved here as
well as a smart card monitor thread in the classes under test, but it is
easy to distinguish the messages from the monitor thread from the messages
from the test cases themselves.

Regards

Jonathan Gossage

Email Address: jonathan@...
